messageBody:
Hello Kent,

> These ideas sound interesting. Can you turn them into test cases?




>
> currently i try to substitute for the junit3.x gui.
> to this end i have to implement
>
> org.junit.runner.notification.RunListener
>
> I think it would be reasonable,
> to extend this interface:
> - start test: report timeout if any
> - ignore test: report reason.
>










// unchanged
public void testRunStarted(Description desc)
public void testRunFinished(Result result)

// the latter two are the values given by @Test
public void testStarted(Description desc*, long timeout, Throwable
expected*)

// unchanged
public void testFinished(Description desc)
public void testFailure(Failure failure)

// reason is the value given by @Ignore
public void testIgnored(Description desc*,**| String| ||*|*reason*)

// fired when RunNotifier.pleaseStop() has been invoked
// and junit is able to react on it
|*public void testRunAborted()*



By the way: |method|| RunNotifier.pleaseStop()||||
exists whereas|||||||||||||||||| JUnitCore||.pleaseStop() ||||||
||does not
I Think it should be added.

By the way: if i give a timeout it turns out that the process goes on in
the background until it finishes.
This makes bad performance to the following tests.
But (i'm not so much into it) maybe there is no way to stop the thread
(Thread.stop() is "@deprecated").
On the other hand, starting each testcase in its own thread would be a
way to stop a testcase quickly
rather than asking kindly "||pleaseStop()".
||I'd prefer this because my testcases are sometimes lengthy.



Hope there are some usable thoughts in here.

Greetings

Ernst
